repo.name: mxnet
repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: compute embed layer for all time index jointly
body:
One potential factor that our char-lstm is slow **might** be because we compute the embedding for each time index separately. This PR is trying to modify the example to allow the embedding to be computed jointly. Not sure if we could get speed up here, but at least the data iter `provide_data` could be more compact.
- [x] modify `SliceChannel`
- [x] modify `Embedding`
- [x] modify `lstm_unroll`
- [x] modify bucketing io
- [x] modify bucketing executor for better memory sharing

Now we have some small speed up. In my local test, original was 500~600 samples/sec, with joint embedding, now we are around 600~700 samples/sec.

title: add neural-style to scala example
body:
It takes 506 epoches to generate the following result:
http://pan.baidu.com/s/1cdVMn8

main different between python version: 
1, optimizer: use Adam instead of SGD and change the leraning rate from 0.1f to 10f,
   because there was some problems when using SGD, or may be I was not implemented it correctly.

2, use gaussian blur for image denoising because I am not yet find anything library of java or scala that implemented the chambolle denoising algorithm.

run: 
java -Xmx1024m -cp scala-package/assembly/linux-x86_64-gpu/target/_:scala-package/examples/target/_:scala-package/examples/target/classes/lib/\* ml.dmlc.mxnet.examples.neuralstyle.NeuralStyle --content-image input/IMG_4343.jpg  --style-image input/starry_night.jpg --model-path model/vgg19.params --output-dir output

title: add initial image argument to neural-style example
body: This adds a feature to set the initial image to be optimized from the command line for the neural-style example. This can be useful if you want to first run the program with a smaller max_long_edge, then use that for the initial image for a longer max_long_edge as this can help with speed optimizations. This may also be useful for general experimentation.

repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: More imperative friendly high level model API (modules)
body:
This is a work-in-progress attempt to refactor the current high-level model API. Because the refactoring is major, to avoid breaking existing code, I started a different set of API. The main component is `Module`, which looks very similar to Torch's modules. We will have both intermediate-level API like `forward`, `backward` on modules, as well as high-level API like `fit`, `score`. The end goal is to allow the modules to be easily composed with high-level imperative API.

TODOs:
- [x] intermediate-level API `forward`, `backward`, `update`, etc.
- [x] high-level API `fit`, `predict`, `score`
- [x] running example, MNIST & CIFAR-10
- [x] `BucketingModule` and ptb example
- [x] model saving and loading
- [ ] ~~`SequentialModule`: a container that connect multiple `Module`s sequentially~~
  - will come in another PR
- [x] comments and docs

title: Using attributes to enable mirroring for an operator
body:
The user can now put `{'force_mirroring': 'true'}` as attributes to force mirroring of a particular operator.

@tqchen I got the following observations, did you observe similar thing when coding up the mirroring feature?
- Some operators (e.g. `BatchNorm`) will crash when mirroring is turned on, with some error like `src/symbol/graph_executor.cc:606: Check failed: (info.type) != (kNotInitialized)`.
- The memory consumption is a bit mysterious to measure, for the cifar10 example. Although I'm only using pycuda to query the total gpu free memory, which is a very rough estimation, I could see that running the exactly same network training (without touching any mirroring option) could actually lead to quite different reporting of memory consumption.

title: [EXECUTOR] Efficient gradient memory aggregation for RNN
body:
see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/722 
The gradient of the embedding need to be summed and previous way of summing so many timestamps was not very efficient. 
- This PR gives a experimental hack to do smarter memory allocation, and use a stream line addition sequence to calculate the gradient
- This can benefit the  RNN with long sequences.
- However, the new optimization relies on the operators to correctly implement AddTo, some of the operators so far are not well tested on AddTo setting, so it is only enabled for summing a lot of gradients.

The environment variable `MXNET_EXEC_INPLACE_GRAD_SUM_CAP` (default to 8) is introduced to control between whether use the new optimization.

title: [R] update mx.symbol.Concat API. close #1578
body:
@firearasi 

I have updated the API for `mx.symbol.Concat`. The code below

``` r
con=list(c1x1,c3x3,cd3x3,cproj)
con$num.args=4
concat = mxnet:::mx.varg.symbol.Concat(con)
```

can be changed into

```
con=list(c1x1,c3x3,cd3x3,cproj)
concat = mx.symbol.Concat(con, num.args=4)
```

Can you help test this?

title: improve data-iter performance for bucketing-rnn example
body: The original data-iter implementation in this example was too naive and does a lot of random number generation in each mini-batch. The improved version runs at a similar speed as a dummy data iteration and should fix the GPU usage issue mentioned in #1644.

title: add LSTM in R
body:
I  wrote LSTM in R using low level symbol interface according to the implementation of rnn in python. It mainy contains two files:
-  `lstm.R` Functions for building a LSTM Network
- `char_lstm.R` demo how to train a character LSTM by using lstm.R

Meanwhile, in order to clear the gradient arrays for the argument `rad.req="add"` of function `mx.simple.bind`, I added a function `mx.exec.update.grad.arrays`.

The following is part of the "char LSTM example" result:

```
Epoch [31] Train: NLL=3.836905475197, Perp=46.3817227414766
Epoch [62] Train: NLL=3.60287136350845, Perp=36.7034722942903
...
Epoch [961] Train: NLL=3.23440136826571, Perp=25.3911672698533
Iter [1] Train: Time: 3.10378745794296 sec, NLL=3.22799701509071, Perp=25.2290728760392
Iter [1] Val: NLL=2.88174404985709, Perp=17.8453692688881
...
Epoch [20553] Train: NLL=1.44098787073839, Perp=4.22486737903258
Iter [21] Train: Time: 3.150696794192 sec, NLL=1.44111800900158, Perp=4.22541723171315
Iter [21] Val: NLL=1.55106124501652, Perp=4.71647286090669
```

title: Add network fine tuning examples
body:
These examples show how to only train the last fully connected layer of a network with all the other parameters loaded from a pre-trained model.

Related issues include https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1313, https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1340,  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1439, and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1568.

title: add use_global_stats option in batch norm layer
body: Hi, I added the "use_global_stats" option in the batch norm layer to use the global mean and variance during the training instead of using the statistics within the batch. It is pretty useful when the batch is small and we want to finetune a pre-trained model.

title: Implementing CNN for Text Classification in MXNet
body:
It is slightly simplified implementation of Kim's [Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification](http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.5882) paper in MXNet.
Recently, I have been learning mxnet for Natural Language Processing (NLP). I followed this nice blog ["Implementing a CNN for Text Classification in Tensorflow" ](http://www.wildml.com/2015/12/implementing-a-cnn-for-text-classification-in-tensorflow/) to reimplement it by mxnet framwork.

repo.name: mxnet
repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: Cross entropy loss and MultiFactorScheduler
body:
Calculate the cross entropy loss for softmax probability output. 

And also provide the MultiFactorScheduler that is able to set `step` to a list of integers to indicate where to reduce the learning rate. It expands the FactorScheduler, as the latter only accepts for a fixed `step`.

title: [Scala] Builder constructor for FeedForward
body:
As @tqchen suggested, an immutable api for FeedForward would be more natural for Scala users. While I reviewed the Feedforward.create in python again, I found it contains too many arguments, which may hard to use: We need to deal with many default values (java even doesn't support default argument) and some arguments may have different types (e.g., the kvstore).

Inspired by deeplearning4j, I think it might be more convenient for users to have the builder&set api, e.g., the piece of codes at the bottom of http://deeplearning4j.org/visualization. This is what I did in this PR.

Trust me, java developers will like this kind of api, because they always use IDE and really enjoy that, they type '.set' then everything pop up.

And I simply move FeedForward class to a single file because Model.scala grows too long.

repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: Scala Package for MXNet
body:
Hi everybody,

I'm really glad to call for a PR request for `mxnet/scala-package`. It brings MXNet to JVM ecosystem.
Please refer to [here](https://github.com/javelinjs/mxnet/blob/scala-package-l/scala-package/README.md) to checkout the build & usage document.

With this package, I look forward to further integrate MXNet with some platforms in Hadoop ecosystems, e.g., Spark and Flink.

Here are the MNIST training results ran on EC2 g2.8xlarge instance with scala-package:

| Model | Devices | KVStore | Epochs | Train Acc | Test Acc | Avg samples/sec |
| --- | :-- | :-: | --: | --: | --: | --: |
| MLP | 1 cpu | local | 10 | 0.9906 | 0.9740 | 7419.98 |
| MLP | 1 gpu | local | 10 | 0.9925 | 0.9770 | 18572.5 |
| Lenet | 1 cpu | local | 3 | 0.9916 | 0.9870 | 717.38 |
| Lenet | 1 gpu | local | 3 | 0.9912 | 0.9867 | 1457.29 |
| Lenet | 4 cpus | local | 10 | 0.9997 | 0.9920 | 1338.4 |
| Lenet | 4 gpus | local | 10 | 0.9998 | 0.9909 | 7882.14 |
| Lenet | 4 gpus | local_allreduce | 10 | 0.9998 | 0.9914 | 13696 |

The Scala Package was first initialized at my own [repo](https://github.com/javelinjs/mxnet-scala). Then @terrytangyuan (Yuan Tang) helped to move it as a part of MXNet main repo. @yanqingmen (Zixuan Huang) joined us after a discussion [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/842). We received great help from @tqchen during the development. Thank you all.

Here's a list of contributions each one made:
- Yizhi: Developed and tested most of the modules. Integrated everything to work.
- Yuan: Helped to setup travis and contributed to parts of Adam.scala, EvalMetric.scala, Initializer.scala, LRScheduler.scala and some functions in NDArray.scala.
- Zixuan: Developed the IO module and tested on mnist and cifar dataset.

I highly suggest to grant Zixuan as committer of MXNet as well. The IO module is a core module,
and we couldn't have moved on without his work. Besides, this module requires some design efforts. His contribution should be as important as Yuan's.

Finally, I opened an [issue](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1591) for Scala Package TODO list. Any suggestions for this PR or the todo list would be highly appreciated. Thank you!

title: Modified R-package clip_gradient to use same ctx
body:
Related to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1323
@thirdwing @Puriney 
Another minor issue is with clip_gradient when ctx in the model is different than mx.ctx.default. This results in an error of the type "Check failed: lhs.ctx() == rhs.ctx() operands context mismatch""
It is due to the redefinition of the grad as an mx.nd.array after the clip:
grad <- mx.nd.array(grad)
this uses the default ctx that can be different to the one used in the model. Setting in your code the default ctx to the same used in the model solves the problem but I don't think this should be a feature.
Changing the nd.array re-definition of grad in optimizer.R to:
grad <- mx.nd.array(grad,ctx(weight))
seems to solve the issue. I don't know if it is possible to avoid doing the conversion of grad back and forth to array and nd.array. 
I've done a PR with this solution.

title: Fix metric error for MAE, MSE, RMSE
body:
**shape error:**

If eval_metric='mse', there will be a error message like:

```
ValueError: Shape of labels (128, 1) does not match shape of predictions (128, 10)
```

The reason is that the following lines in `metric.py` for MAE, MSE, RMSE fucntions:

```
check_label_shapes(label, pred, shape=1)
```

force label and pred have exactly the same shapes. While in this case, label is (128,1), pred is (128,10), it is broadcastable. Hence these checks should be removed.

Whether two ndarray's are broadcastable can be automatically checked by numpy, hence we do not need to add extra codes.

PS: This pull request also allows directly use eval_metrix=mx.metric.Accuracy() for model.fit().

**MAE, MSE, RMSE are not calculated correctly:**

The loss scales should not change with different batch sizes. The original implementation is not calculated correctly. The losses are increasing as the batch sizes decrease! And this bug has been fixed.
